title: Savers have just one month left to open a Help to Buy Isa
text:
Savers have just one month left to open a Help to Buy Isa that allows them to pocket a tax-free bonus of up to £3,000.

For, this type of Isa will be withdrawn from sale on November 30.

But if you open one before this date you will be able to continue using it to save for your first home until November 2029.

Getting on the ladder: The scheme has helped more than 300,000 first-time homebuyers get a foot on the property ladder

The scheme has helped more than 300,000 first-time homebuyers get a foot on the property ladder.

Since it launched in December 2015, the Government has paid out £285 million — an average of £920 per saver — in bonuses.

To qualify for a Help to Buy Isa you must be aged 16 or over and a UK resident.

You can open an account with a lump sum of between £1 and £1,200. After this you can then save up to a maximum of £200 each month.

The idea is that you then use the money you build up to purchase your first home.

And as long as the property costs no more than £450,000 in London, or £250,000 elsewhere in the UK, you will receive a 25 per cent bonus on top of what you have saved.

The maximum bonus you can earn is £3,000 on savings of £12,000. The minimum is £400 so you need to build up at least £1,600 in your account.

If you are planning to buy with your partner, you can each open an account and qualify for up to £6,000 in bonuses.

You can continue saving into your Help to Buy Isa until November 2029 after which time you have another 12 months to claim your bonus.

Interest rates are low at around 2 per cent or 2.5 per cent as the big attraction is the tax-free top-up.

Another small stumbling block with the scheme is you can’t use the bonus as part of the deposit you put down on your home.

This is because the Government does not pay out the bonus until you complete the buying process.

At the deposit stage, you normally need to put down about 10 per cent of the house price.

If you tell your solicitor from the start you are relying on your Help to Buy bonus Isa for the down payment, they may be able to negotiate the deposit down to 5 per cent.

Best rates come from small building societies such as Penrith at 3 per cent, Vernon at 2.85 per cent and Newcastle at 2.56 per cent, but the accounts are on offer to local residents only.

Among the big providers, Barclays pays 2.58 per cent and NatWest, Nationwide and Virgin 2.5 per cent — worth £32 interest a year on savings of £200 a month.

First-time buyers who miss out on a Help to Buy Isa still have the chance to save with the newer Lifetime Isa.

These too pay a 25 per cent government bonus if you use the money to buy your first home or to put towards your retirement.

But the accounts are more complicated than the Help to Buy Isa, and only a handful of providers offer them. They could suit those who can afford to save more than £200 every month.
